questions.q: According to Klimek, what happens when pH goes UP (Alkalosis)?
questions.rationale: Alkalosis makes the body irritable: high HR, high reflexes, seizures. (Except Potassium goes DOWN).

questions.q: What are the signs of Acidosis?
questions.rationale: Acidosis depresses the CNS: lethargy, low HR, respiratory arrest. (Potassium goes UP).

questions.q: Which acid-base imbalance causes Kussmaul respirations?
questions.rationale: Remember MAC Kussmaul (Metabolic Acidosis causes Kussmaul to blow off CO2).

questions.q: What causes a High Pressure ventilator alarm?
questions.rationale: High pressure means the machine has to push harder against resistance (kinked tube, secretions).

questions.q: What are the toxic effects of Aminoglycosides (Gentamicin)?
questions.rationale: Think mice (mycin) have big ears (Oto) and kidneys are shaped like ears (Nephro).

questions.q: When is a trough level drawn?
questions.rationale: Trough is the lowest concentration, always drawn immediately before the next dose is given.

questions.q: What are the symptoms of an "Upper" overdose?
questions.rationale: Uppers stimulate the CNS; everything goes UP.

questions.q: What is the priority for a "Downer" overdose?
questions.rationale: Downers depress the CNS; too much can stop breathing.

questions.q: What happens during withdrawal from a Downer?
questions.rationale: The body was suppressed; remove the suppressant and the body rebounds upward (seizures, tachycardia).

questions.q: How should Potassium never be administered?
questions.rationale: IV Push potassium causes instant cardiac arrest. Always dilute in a bag.

questions.q: What is the effect of Calcium Channel Blockers?
questions.rationale: They are negative inotropes, chronotropes, and dromotropes (weaken, slow, and block conduction).

questions.q: Why are Beta Blockers contraindicated in Asthma?
questions.rationale: Non-selective beta blockers block beta-2 receptors in the lungs, causing constriction.

questions.q: Which lab monitors Coumadin (Warfarin)?
questions.rationale: PT/INR is for Coumadin. PTT is for Heparin.

questions.q: What patient teaching is needed for Baclofen (Lioresal)?
questions.rationale: It relaxes muscles and sedates the CNS; combining with alcohol enhances sedation.

questions.q: What drug treats Malignant Hyperthermia?
questions.rationale: Dantrolene acts directly on skeletal muscle to stop the rigidity and heat production.

questions.q: How does Kayexalate work?
options: Exchanges Sodium for Potassium in the gut
questions.rationale: It acts as a resin in the bowel, trading sodium ions for potassium ions, which are pooped out.

questions.q: Which insulin can be given IV drip?
questions.rationale: Regular insulin is the only one safe for IV administration.

questions.q: When do you draw a peak level for an IV drug?
questions.rationale: This captures the highest concentration in the blood.

questions.q: When are Standard Precautions used?
questions.rationale: Standard precautions apply to contact with blood, body fluids, non-intact skin, and mucous membranes for all patients.

questions.q: Which diseases require Contact Precautions?
options: MRSA, RSV, Staph, Wound infections, Enteric (C-diff)
questions.rationale: Contact is for anything transmitted by touching skin or surfaces (MRS. WEE mnemonic).

questions.q: Which diseases require Droplet Precautions?
options: Sepsis, Scarlet Fever, Strep, Pertussis, Pneumonia, Flu, Meningitis
questions.rationale: Droplets travel 3 feet; a mask is required. (SPIDERMAN mnemonic).

questions.q: Which diseases require Airborne Precautions?
questions.rationale: Tiny particles float in the air. MTV mnemonic: Measles, TB, Varicella.

questions.q: What is the correct order for putting on PPE?
questions.rationale: Start big (Gown), move up to face (Mask/Goggles), end with hands (Gloves).

questions.q: What is the correct order for removing PPE?
questions.rationale: Remove dirtiest first (Gloves), protect face/airway last (Mask).

questions.q: How often must a restraint order be renewed for an adult?
questions.rationale: Restraints are highly regulated; orders expire daily.

questions.q: What is the COAL mnemonic for canes?
questions.rationale: You hold the cane on the strong side to support the weak side.

questions.q: Use an even-numbered gait (2 or 4) when weakness is...?
questions.rationale: If both legs are weak (bilateral), use 2-point or 4-point. If one leg is broken (unilateral/odd), use 3-point.

questions.q: Who is the priority patient?
questions.rationale: The patient with a new, changing, or unstable condition always comes first.

questions.q: In a tie for priority, use the modifying phrase to find the...?
questions.rationale: If two patients are unstable, prioritize the one with the more vital organ failure (Brain/Lung vs Kidney).

questions.q: Can an LPN perform an admission assessment?
questions.rationale: Admission/Discharge assessments require advanced judgment and planning; RN only.

questions.q: Can a UAP take vitals on a stable patient?
questions.rationale: Routine vitals on stable patients are within the UAP scope.

questions.q: What is the difference between Laminectomy and Laminotomy?
questions.rationale: Ectomy removes the whole lamina; Otomy removes a small part to make space.

questions.q: What is the antidote for Digoxin toxicity?
questions.rationale: Digibind binds to digoxin molecules and inactivates them. Signs of toxicity: nausea, visual changes (green/yellow halos), bradycardia.

questions.q: What is the antidote for Coumadin (Warfarin) overdose?
questions.rationale: Vitamin K reverses Warfarin's anticoagulant effect. Keep PT/INR at 1.5-2 times normal.

questions.q: What is the antidote for Heparin overdose?
questions.rationale: Protamine Sulfate neutralizes Heparin. Keep APTT and PTT at 1.5-2.5 times normal.

questions.q: What is the antidote for opiate/narcotic overdose?
questions.rationale: Narcan (Naloxone) is the opioid antagonist that reverses respiratory depression from morphine, heroin, and other opioids.

questions.q: What is the antidote for Tylenol (Acetaminophen) overdose?
questions.rationale: Mucomyst (N-acetylcysteine) is given as a loading dose plus 17 additional doses to prevent hepatotoxicity from acetaminophen overdose.

questions.q: What is the antidote for Magnesium Sulfate toxicity?
questions.rationale: Calcium Gluconate reverses magnesium toxicity. Signs of Mg toxicity: absent DTRs, respirations <12, urine output <30 mL/hr, fetal bradycardia.

questions.q: What is the antidote for cholinergic medication toxicity (Myasthenic Bradycardia)?
questions.rationale: Atropine is an anticholinergic that blocks excess acetylcholine effects (bradycardia, excessive secretions).

questions.q: What is the antidote for Methotrexate toxicity?
questions.rationale: Leucovorin rescue provides folinic acid that normal cells need, counteracting Methotrexate's folate-blocking effects.

questions.q: What is the therapeutic range for Dilantin (Phenytoin)?
questions.rationale: Dilantin therapeutic range is 10-20 mcg/mL. Side effects include gingival hyperplasia.

questions.q: What is the therapeutic range for Lithium?
questions.rationale: Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic range (0.5-1.5 mEq/L). Blood levels above 1.5 indicate toxicity.

questions.q: What is the therapeutic PT/INR range for a patient on Coumadin?
questions.rationale: Normal PT is 11-12.5 sec. Therapeutic INR on Warfarin is 1.5-2 times normal (INR 2-3 for most conditions).

questions.q: What is the therapeutic APTT/PTT range for a patient on Heparin?
questions.rationale: Normal APTT is 60-70 sec. Therapeutic on Heparin is 1.5-2.5 times the control value.

questions.q: What heart rate must be checked before giving Digoxin?
options: If HR < 60, hold the medication and notify the physician
questions.rationale: Digoxin slows the heart. If apical pulse is below 60 bpm, hold the dose and notify the provider to prevent dangerous bradycardia.

questions.q: What should the nurse teach a patient on Warfarin about diet?
options: Maintain consistent Vitamin K intake; do not change it
questions.rationale: Vitamin K counteracts Warfarin. Don't eliminate it, but keep intake consistent so the dose remains effective and predictable.

questions.q: What drugs should a patient on Warfarin avoid?
options: Aspirin, NSAIDs, and other blood thinners
questions.rationale: Aspirin and NSAIDs inhibit platelet function and increase bleeding risk on top of Warfarin's anticoagulation.

questions.q: What is the normal arterial blood pH range?
questions.rationale: Normal pH is 7.35-7.45. Below 7.35 = acidosis. Above 7.45 = alkalosis.

questions.q: What is the normal PaCO2 range?
questions.rationale: Normal CO2 is 35-45 mmHg. CO2 is the respiratory driver: high CO2 = respiratory acidosis, low CO2 = respiratory alkalosis.

questions.q: What is the normal HCO3 (bicarbonate) range?
questions.rationale: Normal HCO3 is 21-28 mEq/L. HCO3 is the metabolic driver: high = metabolic alkalosis, low = metabolic acidosis.

questions.q: A patient has pH 7.30, CO2 55, HCO3 24. What is this?
questions.rationale: pH is low (acidosis). CO2 is high (the respiratory driver is causing it). HCO3 is normal (not compensating yet). This is uncompensated respiratory acidosis.

questions.q: A patient has pH 7.50, CO2 28, HCO3 24. What is this?
questions.rationale: pH is high (alkalosis). CO2 is low (the patient is hyperventilating, blowing off CO2). HCO3 is normal. This is respiratory alkalosis.

questions.q: What causes a Low Pressure ventilator alarm?
options: Disconnection or leak in the circuit
questions.rationale: Low pressure means air is escaping: disconnected tubing, cuff leak, or loose connections. Check all connections first.

questions.q: What is the first action when any ventilator alarm sounds?
questions.rationale: Always assess the patient first. If the patient is in distress, disconnect the vent and bag manually (Ambu bag) while troubleshooting.

questions.q: What food must be avoided with grapefruit juice interactions?
questions.rationale: Grapefruit inhibits CYP3A4 enzyme, increasing blood levels of many drugs including Ca++ channel blockers and statins to toxic levels.

questions.q: When should statins (Lipitor) be taken?
questions.rationale: Cholesterol synthesis peaks at night, so statins are most effective when taken in the evening. Avoid grapefruit juice.

questions.q: What should a patient do after the first dose of an ACE Inhibitor?
options: Stay in bed for 3 hours due to risk of first-dose hypotension
Take a second dose if BP doesn't drop
questions.rationale: ACE inhibitors can cause severe first-dose hypotension. Stay in bed for 3 hours and rise slowly.

questions.q: What is the common side effect of ACE Inhibitors (-pril drugs)?
questions.rationale: ACE inhibitors (Captopril, Lisinopril, Enalapril) cause a dry, hacking cough due to bradykinin accumulation. Switch to ARB if intolerable.

questions.q: What suffix identifies Beta Blockers?
questions.rationale: Beta blockers end in -olol: Propranolol, Metoprolol, Atenolol. They decrease HR and BP.

questions.q: What suffix identifies ACE Inhibitors?
questions.rationale: ACE inhibitors end in -pril: Captopril, Lisinopril, Enalapril. They block angiotensin-converting enzyme to lower BP.

questions.q: What suffix identifies ARBs (Angiotensin Receptor Blockers)?
questions.rationale: ARBs end in -sartan: Losartan, Valsartan, Irbesartan. They block angiotensin II receptors. Used when ACE inhibitor cough is intolerable.

questions.q: What is the nurse's priority before giving any blood pressure medication?
options: Check blood pressure and heart rate
questions.rationale: Always check BP and HR before giving antihypertensives. Hold if BP or HR are below set parameters and notify the physician.

questions.q: What should the nurse teach about Nitroglycerin (NTG)?
options: Take up to 3 tablets, 5 min apart; if no relief, call 911
questions.rationale: NTG is placed under the tongue (sublingual). Take 1 tablet, wait 5 min, take 2nd, wait 5 min, take 3rd. If still in pain after 3 tabs, call 911.

questions.q: How should Nitroglycerin tablets be stored?
options: In a dark glass container, away from heat and light
questions.rationale: NTG degrades with light, heat, and moisture. Store in original dark glass container with cap tightly closed. Replace every 6 months.

questions.q: What is the normal potassium (K+) range?
questions.rationale: Normal K+ is 3.5-5.0 mEq/L. Both hypo- and hyperkalemia cause dangerous cardiac dysrhythmias.

questions.q: What EKG changes are seen in Hypokalemia?
options: Prominent U waves, depressed ST segment, flat T waves
questions.rationale: Hypokalemia causes flattened T waves, ST depression, and characteristic U waves (extra wave after T wave).

questions.q: What EKG changes are seen in Hyperkalemia?
options: Flat T waves and U waves
Tall, peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, widened QRS
questions.rationale: Hyperkalemia produces tall, peaked (tented) T waves, widened QRS, and can progress to ventricular fibrillation and cardiac arrest.

questions.q: What is the normal sodium (Na+) range?
questions.rationale: Normal Na+ is 136-145 mEq/L. Sodium goes with water: low Na = fluid excess, high Na = dehydration.

questions.q: What is the normal calcium (Ca++) range?
questions.rationale: Normal Ca++ is 9-10.5 mg/dL. Hypocalcemia causes muscle spasms, tetany, and positive Trousseau's/Chvostek's signs.

questions.q: What are the signs of Hypocalcemia?
options: Muscle spasms, tetany, Trousseau's sign, Chvostek's sign, prolonged QT
questions.rationale: Low calcium causes neuromuscular irritability: spasms, tetany, (+) Trousseau's (carpal spasm with BP cuff), (+) Chvostek's (facial twitch with nerve tap).

questions.q: What does Trousseau's Sign indicate?
options: Hypocalcemia (carpal spasm when BP cuff inflated)
questions.rationale: Trousseau's sign: inflating BP cuff above systolic for 3 minutes causes carpal spasm (hand contraction), indicating hypocalcemia.

questions.q: What does Chvostek's Sign indicate?
options: Hypocalcemia (facial twitch when tapping facial nerve)
questions.rationale: Chvostek's sign: tapping the facial nerve in front of the ear causes ipsilateral facial muscle twitching, indicating hypocalcemia.

questions.q: Which diuretic is potassium-sparing?
questions.rationale: Spironolactone (Aldactone) saves potassium by blocking aldosterone. Watch for hyperkalemia. Also includes Triamterene and Amiloride.

questions.q: Which diuretic wastes potassium and requires potassium monitoring?
questions.rationale: Loop diuretics (Lasix, Bumex) and Thiazides (HCTZ) waste potassium. Monitor K+ levels and supplement as needed.

questions.q: What teaching is important for patients on loop diuretics (Lasix)?
options: Eat potassium-rich foods (bananas, oranges, potatoes) and take in the morning
questions.rationale: Loop diuretics cause K+ loss. Eat potassium-rich foods, take in the morning to avoid nocturia, and monitor for signs of hypokalemia.

questions.q: What is the antidote for benzodiazepine overdose?
questions.rationale: Flumazenil (Romazicon) competitively antagonizes benzodiazepines at the GABA receptor, reversing sedation.

questions.q: What are the 5 Rights of Medication Administration?
options: Right patient, drug, dose, route, time
Right doctor, nurse, pharmacy, patient, dose
Right drug, patient, room, chart, label
Right form, color, size, shape, label
questions.rationale: The 5 Rights: Right Patient, Right Drug, Right Dose, Right Route, Right Time. Always verify all five before giving any medication.

questions.q: What should the nurse do if a medication error occurs?
options: Assess the patient, notify the physician, complete an incident report, and document
Document in the chart and do nothing else
questions.rationale: After a med error: assess the patient first, notify the provider, implement orders, complete an incident/occurrence report, and document the patient's response.

questions.q: What class of drugs ends in -mycin or -micin?
questions.rationale: Aminoglycosides: Gentamicin, Tobramycin, Amikacin. Monitor for ototoxicity (hearing loss/tinnitus) and nephrotoxicity (rising BUN/creatinine).

questions.q: What must be monitored when a patient is on Vancomycin?
options: Trough levels, renal function, and watch for Red Man Syndrome
questions.rationale: Vancomycin is nephrotoxic and ototoxic. Red Man Syndrome (flushing, hypotension) occurs if infused too rapidly. Always infuse over 60+ minutes.

questions.q: What is Red Man Syndrome?
options: Flushing, rash, and hypotension from rapid Vancomycin infusion
questions.rationale: Red Man Syndrome is a histamine-mediated reaction from infusing Vancomycin too quickly. Slow the rate and premedicate with antihistamines.

questions.q: What is the priority assessment before giving a first dose of any antibiotic?
questions.rationale: Always check allergies before antibiotics. Penicillin allergy may cross-react with cephalosporins. Watch for anaphylaxis with the first dose.

questions.q: What is Rifampin used for and what should patients be warned about?
options: Treat TB; turns body fluids rust/orange/red
questions.rationale: Rifampin is a key TB drug that turns urine, tears, sweat, and other body fluids orange/red. It also reduces effectiveness of oral contraceptives.

questions.q: What side effect is associated with Pyridium (Phenazopyridine)?
questions.rationale: Pyridium is a bladder analgesic that turns urine orange/red/pink. It is NOT an antibiotic and only relieves pain. Warn patients about staining.

questions.q: What must be assessed before and after giving an opioid analgesic?
options: Respiratory rate, level of consciousness, and pain level
questions.rationale: Opioids depress respirations. Hold if RR < 12. Assess LOC (sedation precedes resp depression) and pain before/after for effectiveness.

questions.q: At what respiratory rate should the nurse hold an opioid?
questions.rationale: Hold opioids and notify the physician if RR is below 12 breaths/minute. Naloxone (Narcan) should be readily available.

questions.q: What is the common side effect of opioids that requires a standing order?
questions.rationale: Opioids slow GI motility causing constipation. A bowel regimen (stool softeners, laxatives, fluids, fiber) should be started with opioid therapy.

questions.q: What is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score that indicates coma?
questions.rationale: GCS < 8 = coma; intubation is often required. GCS ranges from 3 (worst) to 15 (fully alert).

questions.q: What is the RACE protocol for a fire emergency?
options: Rescue patients, Activate alarm, Contain fire (close doors), Extinguish/Evacuate
questions.rationale: RACE: Rescue patients in immediate danger, Activate fire alarm, Contain the fire (close doors/windows), Extinguish if small or Evacuate.

questions.q: What does PASS stand for for fire extinguisher use?
options: Pull pin, Aim at base of fire, Squeeze handle, Sweep side to side
questions.rationale: PASS: Pull the pin, Aim at the base of the fire (not the flames), Squeeze the handle, Sweep side to side.

questions.q: What is the purpose of a trough draw in therapeutic drug monitoring?
options: To measure the lowest drug concentration to ensure it stays above minimum effective level
questions.rationale: The trough level (drawn just before the next dose) confirms the drug level hasn't dropped below the therapeutic minimum.

questions.q: What are the symptoms of Digoxin toxicity?
options: Nausea, vomiting, visual disturbances (green-yellow halos), bradycardia
questions.rationale: Dig toxicity: GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, anorexia), visual changes (green-yellow halos, blurred vision), and cardiac dysrhythmias (bradycardia). Check K+ (hypokalemia increases toxicity).

questions.q: What electrolyte imbalance increases the risk of Digoxin toxicity?
questions.rationale: Low potassium competes with Digoxin for the same binding sites, increasing cardiac sensitivity to Digoxin.

questions.q: What class of drug should be used cautiously with patients on Warfarin?
options: Antibiotics (many alter Vitamin K production by gut flora, changing INR)
questions.rationale: Many antibiotics kill gut bacteria that produce Vitamin K, potentiating Warfarin's effect and increasing bleeding risk. Monitor INR closely.

questions.q: What patient teaching is essential for Phenytoin (Dilantin)?
options: Take on an empty stomach only
Good oral hygiene (gingival hyperplasia), do not stop abruptly (seizures), avoid alcohol
questions.rationale: Dilantin causes gingival hyperplasia (gum overgrowth) - meticulous oral care needed. Never stop abruptly (status epilepticus). Alcohol lowers seizure threshold.

questions.q: What happens if you abruptly stop an anticonvulsant?
questions.rationale: Abruptly stopping anticonvulsants can trigger rebound seizures including status epilepticus, a medical emergency. Always taper.

questions.q: What is the nurse's role in informed consent?
options: Explain the procedure to the patient
Witness the patient's signature and ensure they understand
Sign on behalf of the patient
questions.rationale: The physician explains the procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives. The nurse's role is to witness the signature and verify the patient understands.

questions.q: Which task can the nurse NEVER delegate?
questions.rationale: Assessment, teaching, evaluation, and anything requiring clinical judgment are RN-only activities that cannot be delegated to LPNs or UAPs.

questions.q: What tasks can be delegated to an LPN?
options: Admission assessment and care plan development
Routine wound care, medication administration, data collection on stable patients
questions.rationale: LPNs can perform routine skills (wound care, med admin, VS, data collection) on stable patients under RN supervision. They cannot assess, plan, teach, or evaluate.

questions.q: What is the order of priority when using Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs for NCLEX?
options: Physiological needs first, then safety, then love/belonging
questions.rationale: Maslow's: meet physiological needs first (airway, breathing, circulation, food, water), then safety, then psychosocial needs.
